rome — no sooner had workers hoisted a 72-foot tall norway spruce in rome’s central piazza venezia this month than the mocking began. newline_char newline_char the tree was quickly nicknamed spelacchio, or mangy, because so many of its dead needles were dropping off, leaving the tree looking a bit bare. chatter spread quickly on social media where romans traded jokes about the spruce and criticized its sad appearance. newline_char newline_char insults quickly turned to intrigue as the italian media plumbed the tree’s costs, questioned how it had been transported to the city and analyzed its state of health. newline_char newline_char “it has clearly been traumatized,” one expert declared. newline_char newline_char a consumer rights group asked an administrative court, which has oversight over government spending, to investigate what it described as a “shameful spectacle for citizens and tourists” and demanded that the tree be removed immediately.

summary: The Christmas tree in Rome's Piazza Venezia is not having a good year. The tree, nicknamed "Spelacchio" or "mangy" by locals, arrived early this month from the Trentino region, near Italy's border with Austria. It is estimated to have cost Italian taxpayers 48,000 euros, or $57,000. The tree has been shedding its needles and is now nearly see-through. Some believe that the tree was unsettled by its trip or was ill on departure. There is not enough time, money, or political will to replace the tree, and so Spelacchio will stay in Piazza Venezia through the holidays. The tree has become a metaphor for what's wrong with the city, and the country.

rome — if the paragon of all christmas trees is the one in front of the rockefeller center in new york — first erected, mind you, by an italian in 1931 — the prize for most pitiful must go to the one that stands in rome’s piazza venezia this year. just days after it was put up, it began to gray and shed its needles, and soon it had become nearly see-through. the tree cuts so sad and forlorn a figure that it has been nicknamed spelacchio, or mangy. newline_char newline_char spelacchio arrived in rome early this month from the trentino region, near italy’s border with austria, and what with transport expenses and decorations, the 70-foot fir is estimated to have cost italian taxpayers 48,000 euros, or $57,000. it’s not clear what has ailed it. maybe spelacchio was unsettled by the trip; perhaps it was ill on departure. by way of explanation, antimo palumbo, a tree historian who was standing by spelacchio’s side on friday morning, pointed at the concrete all over its roots. “you see that?” he told me. “they decided to pour the concrete to keep it steady, but that killed it instead.” newline_char newline_char there isn’t enough time, money or political will to replace the tree, and so spelacchio the mangy will stay in piazza venezia through the holidays, and for many locals it has already become a metaphor for what’s wrong with the city, and the country. newline_char newline_char traffic in rome is chronically congested, public transport is inefficient, trash collection is slow and sporadic. early hopes about virginia raggi, who was elected mayor last year on an anti-establishment agenda, promptly faded amid familiar allegations of corruption and nepotism.

summary: – if you were thinking that rome's christmas tree was the most pitiful thing in the world, think again. after a week, the 70-foot-tall fir has started to gray and shed its needles, and soon it has become nearly see-through, reports abc news. it will stay in piazza venezia through the holidays, but the city isn't about to spend any more money on it. "they decided to pour the concrete to keep it steady, but that killed it instead," one expert tells me. "it has clearly become a metaphor for what's wrong with the city, and the country."

summary: – when it comes to the most pitiful christmas tree, it's the one in rome. a 72-foot norway spruce was erected in the city's piazza venezia this month, but soon became so sad and forlorn that it has been nicknamed spelacchio, or mangy. just days after it was put up, it began to gray and shed its needles, and soon it had become nearly see-through, reports the guardian. what's more, the tree cost $57,000 in transport expenses and decorations, and a consumer rights group is investigating what it's described as a "shameful spectacle for citizens and tourists." the tree will remain in rome through the holidays, but will be removed if it doesn't improve its condition. it's not clear if the trip to rome was smooth, but a historian tells iol that concrete poured over the roots of the tree apparently killed it. "they decided to pour the concrete to keep it steady, but that killed it instead," he tells the guardian. (a tree like spelacchio is supposed to be meant to symbolize what's wrong with the city and its people.) . (a tree like spelacchio can be found in front of the rockefeller center.)

documents: anissa weier is brought into court for a hearing last month. on thursday, her attorney said she would plead not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect in the slender man case. she and morgan geyser are accused of stabbing another girl. (photo: michael sears / milwaukee journal sentinel) newline_char newline_char anissa weier plans to enter a plea of not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect in the slender man stabbing case next week. newline_char newline_char weier's co-defendant, morgan geyser, had already entered such a plea, often referred to as ngi, at a hearing last month. newline_char newline_char at the time, prosecutors pressed the judge to inquire whether weier might go the same route, since it requires the court to appoint doctors to examine the defendant and report whether their condition would support the plea. one of weier's attorneys, maura mcmahon, said the defense had not yet decided. newline_char newline_char but in a pleading filed this week, mcmahon indicated that weier now wants to change her not guilty plea to the insanity plea. a hearing was set for sept. 9 for that change of plea. newline_char newline_char weier and geyser, both 14, were 12 when prosecutors say they plotted and attempted to kill their sixth-grade classmate and friend payton leutner in may 2014. newline_char newline_char archive: slender man case coverage newline_char newline_char leutner was stabbed 19 times and left for dead in a waukesha park the morning after a sleepover party for geyser's 12th birthday, but managed to crawl near a path, where she was found by a passing bicyclist. newline_char newline_char both defendants later told police they were trying to either impress or avoid the wrath of slender man, a fictional internet boogeyman the girls said they believed would harm them or their families if they didn't kill their friend. newline_char newline_char they remain charged as adults with attempted first-degree intentional homicide, after efforts to have their cases transferred to juvenile court were denied. newline_char newline_char a defendant entering an ngi plea contends that at the time she committed a crime, a mental disease or defect prevented her from appreciating the wrongfulness of her action, or from conforming her conduct to the law. newline_char newline_char someone found not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect is typically committed to a state mental hospital for treatment. newline_char newline_char geyser, who has been diagnosed with early onset schizophrenia, has already spent months at winnebago mental health institute under a separate civil commitment. newline_char newline_char during earlier hearings, mental health experts testified that weier was competent to proceed with the case, but had not done more extensive evaluations required for an ngi review. she remains at a west bend juvenile detention center. newline_char newline_char no trial date has been set in the case. newline_char newline_char read or share this story: http://on.jsonl.in/2civi3x

two girls accused of trying to kill a classmate to please horror character slender man want jurors from outside their home county to decide their trials. newline_char newline_char newline_char newline_char morgan geyser's attorneys filed a motion this week seeking jurors from outside waukesha county because of heavy media coverage. geyser has pleaded not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect. newline_char newline_char newline_char newline_char a letter the other girl's defense attorneys submitted to the court seeks outside jurors as well. the letter noted that girl plans to plead not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect. newline_char newline_char newline_char newline_char investigators say geyser and anissa weier, who were 12 at the time of the 2014 attack, plotted for months before luring the victim, who also was 12, into some woods and repeatedly stabbing her. the girls hoped killing her would please slender man, a demon-like character in online stories. newline_char newline_char newline_char newline_char the victim crawled out of the woods to get help. newline_char newline_char both girls face an attempted homicide charge in adult court. their attorneys had been fighting to move them into juvenile court but a state appeals court in july ruled they should remain in adult court. newline_char newline_char newline_char newline_char

summary: – one of two Wisconsin girls accused of trying to kill a classmate to please a fictional online boogeyman plans to change her plea to not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect, her attorney says. anissa weier, 14, had previously indicated she would plead not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect, reports the waukesha journal sentinel. but in a filing this week, her attorney says she wants to change that to a guilty plea. weier's co-defendant, morgan geyser, 14, had previously pleaded not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect. both girls are charged as adults with attempted first-degree intentional homicide. prosecutors say the girls planned the attack as a way to please Slender Man, a demon they believed lurked in the woods near their home.

summary: – two girls accused of trying to kill a classmate to please horror character slender man have taken the unusual approach of pleading not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect, the milwaukee journal sentinel reports. anissa weier and morgan geyser, who were 12 at the time of the 2014 attack, plotted for months before luring the victim, who also was 12, into some woods and repeatedly stabbing her. the victim crawled out of the woods to get help and was found by a passing bicyclist. weier and geyser face an attempted homicide charge in adult court. their attorneys had been fighting to move them into juvenile court but a state appeals court in july ruled they should remain in adult court. but in a pleading filed this week, weier's attorney indicated that she wants to change her not guilty plea to the insanity plea. a hearing was set for sept. 9 for that change. a defendant entering an ngi plea contends that at the time she committed a crime, a mental disease or defect prevented her from appreciating the wrongfulness of her action, or from conforming her conduct to the law. someone found not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect is typically committed to a state mental hospital for treatment. weier's attorneys are seeking jurors from outside waukesha county because of heavy media coverage.

summary: – after a decade of marriage, taye diggs and idina menzel have decided to separate, people confirms. the couple, who met while costarring in the original broadway production of rent in 1995, have jointly decided to separate at this time, reps for the couple tell people exclusively. diggs is currently starring in the best man holiday, while menzel is currently voicing a character in frozen. the couple married in 2003 and had a son, walker, in september 2009. menzel, a tony award winner for wicked who's currently voicing a character in frozen, spoke to people about the marriage earlier this year, saying it wasn't always smooth sailing. "i'm not going to glamorize it or glorify it – we go through tough times like everybody else, but we love each other very much," she said. "we try not to be away from each other for more than two weeks at a time, and we try to find new ways to communicate."

summary: – after a decade of marriage, taye diggs and idina menzel have separated, people report. "their primary focus and concern is for their son," a rep for menzel tells weekly. the couple met as costars in the broadway musical rent in the mid-1990s, and reprised their roles in the 2005 film adaptation. they married in 2003 and had a son, walker, in september 2009. as recently as october, diggs told us, "we're doing good!" when congratulated on his milestone wedding anniversary at the men's health 25th anniversary party in new york city. "i'm not going to glamorize it or glorify it – we go through tough times like everybody else, but we love each other very much. we try not to be away from each other for more than two weeks at a time, and we try to find new ways to communicate," he told the crowd. but the couple's troubles weren't as smooth as they might have been: diggs has been accused of cheating, and menzel has been accused of plotting to break up with billy umeh. still, the 42-year-old is currently starring in the best man holiday film. .

documents: paris (ap) — the pompidou centre in paris hopes to display a long-vanished picasso painting in may, now that it has been recovered by u.s. customs authorities. newline_char newline_char this undated photo provided by the united states department of justice, shows a cubist painting entitled “the hairdresser” by pablo picasso. authorities say the painting worth millions of dollars was... (associated press) newline_char newline_char the 1911 cubist painting "the hairdresser," worth millions of dollars, was reported missing from a pompidou storeroom in 2001. it was smuggled into the u.s. in december from belgium. newline_char newline_char pompidou director alain seban said the discovery comes as a "true comfort" at a time when the cultural world is reeling from an islamic state video showing the destruction of statues in iraq. newline_char newline_char seban said in a statement friday that he hopes the work can be exhibited again publicly in may. newline_char newline_char u.s. and french authorities have not announced any arrests in the case.

a stolen picasso worth millions of dollars was shipped to the u.s. in a package that described it as a $37 "art craft" — but it will soon be on its way back to france. newline_char newline_char federal prosecutors in brooklyn filed papers thursday to forfeit the century-old cubist painting, which was swiped from a museum storeroom in 2001. "a lost treasure has been found," u.s. attorney loretta lynch said in a statement. newline_char newline_char the canvas, titled "la coiffeuse," was bequeathed to france's national museum and was placed in storage at the centre georges pompidou, where staffers discovered it was missing when they received a loan request for it. newline_char newline_char it was shipped by federal express from belgium in december and seized at the port of newark. officials said shipper was identified only as "robert" and the destination was a climate-controlled storage facility in queens. court papers did not indicate whether the sender or intended recipient have been identified. newline_char newline_char la coiffeuse, painted by picasso in 1911. u.s. department of justice newline_char newline_char facebook newline_char newline_char twitter newline_char newline_char google plus newline_char newline_char embed 0:31 autoplay autoplay copy this code to your website or blog newline_char newline_char in-depth newline_char newline_char — tracy connor

a picasso painting missing from paris for more than a decade resurfaced in the united states, where it had been shipped under false pretenses as a $37 holiday-themed “art craft.” newline_char newline_char the 1911 painting, “la coiffeuse,” which translates to “the hairdresser,” was unearthed in december in a fedex shipment from belgium to newark. the canvas had been smuggled out of a storeroom of the centre georges pompidou, the paris museum and arts center, and its whereabouts had not been known. newline_char newline_char on thursday, loretta e. lynch, the united states attorney for the eastern district of new york, filed a civil complaint to forfeit the picasso and return it to france. newline_char newline_char its shipping papers described it as a $37 “art craft/toy” and also read “joyeux noel,” french for “merry christmas.” when federal customs and border protection officials examined the shipment, though, they found the master artist’s work. department of homeland security officials working from long island city, queens, which is within the eastern district of new york’s jurisdiction, then took over. newline_char newline_char the oil painting is owned by the french government; it had been bequeathed to the national museums of france by one of its former directors. it was last exhibited in munich in 1998, and then returned to paris, where it was stored at the pompidou. officials there thought it was safe and sound until they received a loan request for it in 2001, searched the storerooms and could not find it. they declared the painting, then valued more than $2.5 million, stolen. newline_char newline_char on dec. 17, someone going by “robert” with an address in belgium shipped the painting to a climate-controlled warehouse in long island city. the next day, the painting arrived at the port of newark and was seized. newline_char newline_char french museum officials came to new york last month to examine the painting in person alongside historical records and photographs, and they confirmed that it was “la coiffeuse.” newline_char newline_char under federal law, imported merchandise can be seized by the government if it was stolen or smuggled. newline_char newline_char “the market to sell stolen antiquities in the united states is drying up,” anthony scandiffio, deputy special agent in charge of homeland security investigations, which seized the painting after border officials flagged it, said in a statement.

summary: A painting by Picasso that was reported stolen from a Paris museum more than a decade ago has been found in the U.S. The work, "The Hairdresser," was shipped from Belgium to Newark, New Jersey, in December, and was seized by U.S. Customs and Border Protection. It is now being returned to France.

summary: – a 1911 cubist painting worth millions of dollars has been recovered after being mysteriously transported from france to the us nearly a decade ago. the pablo picasso painting, titled la coiffeuse, was reported missing from a pompidou storeroom in paris in 2001 and was last seen in a package shipped to the us from belgium, the ap reports. federal prosecutors in brooklyn filed papers thursday to seize the painting, which was hidden in a climate-controlled storage facility in queens, ny, and will soon be returned to france, reports the new york times. the center for art recovery in paris says it hopes to have the painting back in may, at a time when the cultural world is reeling from islamic state videos showing the destruction of statues in iraq. "this is a true comfort for us at a time when the cultural world is reeling from the islamic state video showing the destruction of statues in iraq," says alain seban, the director of the pompidou centre in paris. "it is a work of art that represents the genius of pablo picasso and was bequeathed to us in 2001 by the master of france's national museum."

summary: – a century-old picasso painting missing from paris for more than a decade resurfaced in the united states under false pretenses as a $37 holiday-themed "art craft," the ap reports. the 1911 painting, called "la coiffeuse," was unearthed in december in a fedex shipment from belgium to newark. the canvas had been smuggled out of a storeroom of the centre georges pompidou, the paris museum and arts center. officials there thought it was safe and sound until they received a loan request for it in 2001. they searched the storerooms and could not find it. on dec. 17, someone going by "robert" with an address in belgium brought the painting to a climate-controlled warehouse in long island city and was seized, the ap reports. the us attorney for the eastern district of new york filed a civil complaint thursday to forfeit the picasso and return it to france. the canvas, titled "la coiffeuse," was bequeathed to the national museums of france in 1998. the pompidou director alain seban said in a statement friday that he hopes the work can be exhibited again publicly in may. no arrests have been made in the case.

documents: relocation of endangered animals carries risks but loss of half of them is highly unusual newline_char newline_char eight out of 14 critically endangered black rhinos have died after being moved to a reserve in southern kenya, wildlife officials have revealed, in what one conservationist described as “a complete disaster”. newline_char newline_char preliminary investigations pointed to salt poisoning as the rhinos tried to adapt to saltier water in their new home, the kenyan ministry of tourism and wildlife said in a statement. it suspended the moving of other rhinos and said the surviving ones were being closely monitored. newline_char newline_char last male northern white rhino is put down read more newline_char newline_char save the rhino estimates there are fewer than 5,500 black rhinos in the world, all of them in africa, while kenya’s black rhino population stands at 750, according to the world wide fund for nature. newline_char newline_char losing the rhinos was “a complete disaster”, the prominent kenyan conservationist paula kahumbu, of wildlifedirect, told the associated press. newline_char newline_char cathy dean, chief executive of save the rhino, said she and international colleagues were shocked and deeply saddened. newline_char newline_char she called for external experts to be called in to carry out a thorough investigation into what went wrong, with the findings published in full. newline_char newline_char dean said the scale of the deaths from the translocation was greater than rhino fatalities caused by poaching so far this year in kenya. newline_char newline_char “it’s an absolute tragedy to lose seven [now eight] animals in this way,” dean said. “the most important thing is for kenya to do a proper inquiry and investigation into what went wrong. for that to happen the kenya wildlife service needs to bring in external vets and translocation specialists from other countries - namibia, for example.” newline_char newline_char the relocation of endangered animals – known as translocation – involves putting them to sleep for the journey and then reviving them in a process that carries risks. but the loss of half of them is highly unusual. newline_char newline_char newline_char newline_char the black rhinos were moved from the nairobi and lake nakuru national parks to a new sanctuary created in tsavo east national park in an operation announced by najib balala, the kenyan tourism minister and carried out in collaboration with wwf kenya. newline_char newline_char in a statement the ministry said its preliminary (associated press) newline_char newline_char nairobi, kenya (ap) — eight critically endangered black rhinos are dead in kenya after wildlife workers moved them from the capital to a new national park, the government said friday, calling the toll "unprecedented" in more than a decade of such transfers. newline_char newline_char preliminary investigations point to salt poisoning as the rhinos tried to adapt to saltier water in their new home, the ministry of tourism and wildlife said in a statement, describing how the animals likely became dehydrated and drank more salty water in a fatal cycle. newline_char newline_char the ministry suspended the ongoing move of rhinos and said the surviving ones in the new park were being closely monitored. newline_char newline_char the loss is "a complete disaster," said prominent kenyan conservationist paula kahumbu of wildlifedirect. newline_char newline_char conservationists in africa have been working hard to protect the black rhino sub-species from poachers targeting them for their horns to supply an illegal asian market. newline_char newline_char in moving a group of 11 rhinos to the newly created tsavo east national park from nairobi last month, the kenya wildlife service said it hoped to boost the population there. the government agency has not said how the rhinos died. fourteen of the animals were to be moved in all. newline_char newline_char "disciplinary action will definitely be taken" if an investigation into the deaths indicates negligence by agency staff, the wildlife ministry said. newline_char newline_char "moving rhinos is complicated, akin to moving gold bullion, it requires extremely careful planning and security due to the value of these rare animals," kahumbu said in a statement. "rhino translocations also have major welfare considerations and i dread to think of the suffering that these poor animals endured before they died." newline_char newline_char transporting wildlife is a strategy used by conservationists to help build up, or even bring back, animal populations. in may, six black rhinos were moved from south africa to chad, restoring the species to the country in north-central africa nearly half a century after it was wiped out there. newline_char newline_char kenya transported 149 rhinos between 2005 and 2017 with eight deaths, the wildlife ministry said. newline_char newline_char according to wwf, black rhino populations declined dramatically in the 20th century, mostly at the hands of european hunters and settlers. between 1960 and 1995 numbers dropped by 98 percent, to fewer than 2,500. newline_char newline_char since then the species has rebounded, although it remains extremely threatened. in addition to poaching the animals also face habitat loss. newline_char newline_char african parks, a johannesburg-based conservation group, said earlier this year that there are fewer than 25,000 rhinos in the african wild, of which about 20 percent are black rhinos and the rest white rhinos. newline_char newline_char in another major setback for conservation, the last remaining male northern white rhino on the planet died in march in kenya, leaving conservationists struggling to save that sub-species using in vitro fertilization. newline_char newline_char ___ newline_char newline_char follow africa news at https://twitter.com/ap_africa

summary: In Kenya, eight critically endangered black rhinos have died after being moved to a new reserve, in what one conservationist has called “a complete disaster”. The relocation of the animals – known as translocation – involves putting them to sleep for the journey and then reviving them in a process that carries risks, but the loss of half of them is highly unusual. Preliminary investigations suggest the rhinos died of salt poisoning as they tried to adapt to saltier water in their new home. The Kenyan government has suspended the moving of other rhinos and said the surviving ones were being closely monitored.

summary: – eight critically endangered black rhinos have died after being moved to a new reserve in southern kenya, wildlife officials say, in what one conservationist describes as "a complete disaster." the animals were among 14 that were moved last year from two national parks in the nairobi and lake nakuru areas to a new sanctuary in the wwf's tsavo east national park, according to the ap. the kenyan ministry of tourism and wildlife says three of the rhinos died of salt poisoning, while the fourth was found to have a brain haemorrhage. while the ministry says it has suspended the moving of other rhinos, it added that the surviving ones are being closely monitored. "it's an absolute tragedy to lose seven [now eight] animals in this way," says the chief executive of save the rhino. "the most important thing is for kenya to do a proper inquiry and investigation into what went wrong." she says the deaths are "unprecedented" given the size of the black rhino population in kenya, which is only 750, and the fact that other countries have successfully relocated rhinos from depleted populations.

(associated press) newline_char newline_char nairobi, kenya (ap) — eight critically endangered black rhinos are dead in kenya after wildlife workers moved them from the capital to a new national park, the government said friday, calling the toll "unprecedented" in more than a decade of such transfers. newline_char newline_char preliminary investigations point to salt poisoning as the rhinos tried to adapt to saltier water in their new home, the ministry of tourism and wildlife said in a statement, describing how the animals likely became dehydrated and drank more salty water in a fatal cycle. newline_char newline_char the ministry suspended the ongoing move of rhinos and said the surviving ones in the new park were being closely monitored. newline_char newline_char the loss is "a complete disaster," said prominent kenyan conservationist paula kahumbu of wildlifedirect. newline_char newline_char conservationists in africa have been working hard to protect the black rhino sub-species from poachers targeting them for their horns to supply an illegal asian market. newline_char newline_char in moving a group of 11 rhinos to the newly created tsavo east national park from nairobi last month, the kenya wildlife service said it hoped to boost the population there. the government agency has not said how the rhinos died. fourteen of the animals were to be moved in all. newline_char newline_char "disciplinary action will definitely be taken" if an investigation into the deaths indicates negligence by agency staff, the wildlife ministry said. newline_char newline_char "moving rhinos is complicated, akin to moving gold bullion, it requires extremely careful planning and security due to the value of these rare animals," kahumbu said in a statement. "rhino translocations also have major welfare considerations and i dread to think of the suffering that these poor animals endured before they died." newline_char newline_char transporting wildlife is a strategy used by conservationists to help build up, or even bring back, animal populations. in may, six black rhinos were moved from south africa to chad, restoring the species to the country in north-central africa nearly half a century after it was wiped out there. newline_char newline_char kenya transported 149 rhinos between 2005 and 2017 with eight deaths, the wildlife ministry said. newline_char newline_char according to wwf, black rhino populations declined dramatically in the 20th century, mostly at the hands of european hunters and settlers. between 1960 and 1995 numbers dropped by 98 percent, to fewer than 2,500. newline_char newline_char since then the species has rebounded, although it remains extremely threatened. in addition to poaching the animals also face habitat loss. newline_char newline_char african parks, a johannesburg-based conservation group, said earlier this year that there are fewer than 25,000 rhinos in the african wild, of which about 20 percent are black rhinos and the rest white rhinos. newline_char newline_char in another major setback for conservation, the last remaining male northern white rhino on the planet died in march in kenya, leaving conservationists struggling to save that sub-species using in vitro fertilization. newline_char newline_char ___ newline_char newline_char follow africa news at https://twitter.com/ap_africa

summary: – eight out of 14 critically endangered black rhinos have died after being moved to a reserve in southern kenya, wildlife officials have revealed, in what one conservationist described as "a complete disaster." in a statement the kenyan ministry of tourism and wildlife said the animals died of salt poisoning as they tried to adapt to saltier water in their new home. it suspended the moving of other rhinos and said the surviving ones were being closely monitored. the relocation of endangered animals – known as translocation – involves putting them to sleep for the journey and then reviving them in a process that carries risks. but the loss of half of them is highly unusual, the ap reports. the world wide fund for nature estimates there are fewer than 5,500 black rhinos in the world, all of them in africa, while kenya’s black rhino population stands at 750. in march, the last male northern white rhino on the planet, an older bull named sudan, was put down by kenyan vets after becoming ill; in may, three more were shot dead inside a specially protected sanctuary in northern kenya and had their horns removed. transporting wildlife is a strategy used by conservationists to help build up, or even bring back, animal populations. in may, six black rhinos were moved from south africa to chad, restoring the species to the country nearly half a century after it was wiped out there.

summary: Rihanna was spotted out and about in New York City in a see-through bra and skirt, and later at a basketball game with her family and ex-boyfriend Chris Brown. There is speculation that Rihanna and Brown are seeing each other in private, and that her management is struggling to deal with her rebellious behavior.

documents: rihanna stepped out in new york in one of her most revealing daytime looks yet – as she continues to rebel against handlers who have been urging her to tone down her wild behavior. newline_char newline_char the singer was seen shopping in soho in a revealing, and see-through, tiny pink strapless bra with a pleated skirt, showing off her flat stomach and toned arms. newline_char newline_char the star, who matched her look with converse sneakers, sunglasses and bright yellow talon nails, wandered around the soho shops with girlfriends before heading to da silvano for an early dinner. newline_char newline_char she cancelled a trip to the uk last week insisting she needed to spend more time with her family and her grandmother, dolly, who is suffering from cancer. she was spotted catching the miami heat game on saturday at 40/40 with her family, including her grandfather, and her group was later joined by her ex chris brown. rihanna and brown later headed with their respective entourages to meatpacking hotspot sl. newline_char newline_char while sources told the uk’s closer magazine that rihanna’s friend and manager jay-z has ordered her to “go to rehab,” sources tell page six that this is not the case, and the real issue is that rihanna is at the center of a management struggle at roc nation about how to deal with her rebellious behavior, and refusal to stay away from brown. newline_char newline_char one source told page six, “rihanna feels she has worked hard, and rightly deserves to enjoy her huge success. she has rebelled against her management and her record label execs who want her to tone her lifestyle down and work more. she has been taking more vacations, wearing more wild outfits, posting more on twitter. her message is that she’s an artist, and will live her life how she likes.”

rihanna and chris brown are “seeing a lot of each other in private,” sources say, and brown even joined her and her family to cheer on the miami heat over the weekend. newline_char newline_char the two stars have partied at the same clubs twice in the past two weeks but kept a coy distance. but sources tell page six they’re very close in private. newline_char newline_char and in a sign that brown has been forgiven for his infamous 2009 attack on rihanna, he joined her family, including her grandfather lionel brathwaite and various cousins, at jay-z’s 40/40 on saturday to watch the heat beat the celtics. newline_char newline_char a source told us, “rihanna arrived first in a yellow cab, with her family and friends, and was escorted to a private room. brown arrived a little later and joined her and her family. they sat on the same couch together rooting for the heat. there was no sign of his girlfriend.” newline_char newline_char the pair then left separately — with brown exiting first with his pals — while rihanna and her family remained behind to watch the manny pacquiao–timothy bradley fight. newline_char newline_char as we reported yesterday, rihanna and brown reunited later at meatpacking club sl — where they kept a cool distance. they partied in separate booths but kept a close eye on each other. he sent over two bottles of ace of spades champagne. newline_char newline_char meanwhile, sources say rihanna’s management is deeply divided on how to deal with the “chris brown issue.” one source said, “everyone in the business assumes she and chris are getting back together, and it is only a matter of time before they’ll be more public about it. newline_char newline_char “it’s like she is testing the water — first they work on music together, then they hang out in a friendly way, so the public won’t be completely shocked when they step out together publicly. newline_char newline_char “there is also a tug of war at roc nation over the final say on what she is doing. but everyone agrees they can’t control rihanna and can’t stop her seeing chris, no matter how much they fear the negative public reaction will be. it means she probably won’t release another album this year, for fear of a backlash.”

summary: – looks like rihanna is having none of it. the troubled singer was spotted in soho yesterday sporting a see-through, tiny pink strapless bra with a pleated skirt, showing off her flat stomach and toned arms, reports heat. the 23-year-old was joined by her grandfather and ex-boyfriend chris brown for the day. wearing converse sneakers, sunglasses, and bright yellow talon nails, she headed to da silvano for an early dinner.

summary: – rihanna stepped out in new york yesterday in one of her most revealing daytime looks yet. the singer wore a see-through, tiny pink strapless bra with a pleated skirt, showing off her flat stomach and toned arms. the star matched her look with converse sneakers, sunglasses, and bright yellow talon nails. she wandered around the soho shops with girlfriends before heading to da silvano for an early dinner. she cancelled a trip to the uk last week insisting she needed to spend more time with her family and her grandmother, dolly, who is suffering from cancer. she was spotted catching the miami heat game on saturday at 40/40 with her family, including her grandfather, and her group was later joined by her ex chris brown. rihanna and brown later headed with their respective entourages to meatpacking hotspot sl. while sources tell the uk’s closer magazine that rihanna’s friend and manager jay-z has ordered her to “go to rehab,” sources tell page six that this is not the case. the real issue is that rihanna is at the center of a management struggle at roc nation about how to deal with her rebellious behavior and refusal to stay away from brown. one source tells page six, “rihanna feels she has worked hard, and rightly deserves to enjoy her huge success. she has rebelled against her management and her record label execs who want her to tone her lifestyle down and work more. she has been taking more vacations, wearing more wild outfits, posting more on twitter. her message is that she’s an artist, and will live her life how she likes."

summary: – here's one of the city's lesser-known dive bars, rated by wcco as the "best burger in town." wcco recommends que viet in st. paul, minnesota, reports the guardian. "it's that amazing. really, it's not a huge place, so don't bring your whole extended family with you." check out the other artsy deals around the city this week: crooked water spirits and thebb boulevardier, reports the minnesota plain dealer. as for fine food, check out the sunshine factory in plymouth, minnesota, reports the minnesota plain dealer. it produces moonshine, one of minneapolis's top distilleries, and has been producing it since the 1970s, reports the minnesota plain dealer. here's a selection of other artsy deals around the city, including the following: madison's, a blue note restaurant, is located in saint paul; british columbia's, a blue note restaurant, is located in south hartford, minnesota; and solomon's, a local dive bar, is located in south hartford. see the rest of the best of minnesota section of the wisconsin daily beast for more options.

newline_char a body believed to be the remains of missing jacksonville woman savannah gold were found late saturday, the jacksonville sheriff’s office said. newline_char newline_char related headlines government shutdown: trump signs bill to temporarily reopen government newline_char newline_char the body was found in a pond off club duclay road — near blanding blvd. — in west jacksonville. newline_char newline_char gold’s coworker at bonefish grill, manager lee rodarte, 28, became a suspect after discrepancies were found in his story, jso said. newline_char newline_char traffic tickets issued to rodarte in 2006 show that he once lived on the same street where the body was found. newline_char newline_char rodarte appeared in court sunday after being booked on charges including murder and tampering with evidence. a judge said he is being held without bond on the murder charge. newline_char newline_char judge ordered rodarte be held without bond on the murder charge. he's also accused of tampering with evidence in savannah gold's death pic.twitter.com/pralgdtb3r — brittney donovan (@brittneydonovan) august 6, 2017 newline_char newline_char lee rodarte, suspect in savannah gold's murder, just had his first appearance in #jacksonville pic.twitter.com/yynhf83ebe — brittney donovan (@brittneydonovan) august 6, 2017 newline_char newline_char raw interview: gold's father, friend make emotional plea newline_char newline_char jso said gold got into rodarte’s car in the parking lot of the restaurant on wednesday evening before her shift. newline_char newline_char they apparently had a fight. the two had an off-and-on relationship, jso said. newline_char newline_char a struggle ensued, jso said, and rodarte appeared to take an object and slash the tire of gold’s car. after a few minutes, he drove away in his own car, jso said. newline_char newline_char confirmed lee rodarte will make his first court appearance this afternoon. he's charged with murder and evidence tampering. @actionnewsjax pic.twitter.com/qadj9hfjfy — christy turner (@christyanjax) august 6, 2017 newline_char newline_char rodarte was arrested at the mandarin restaurant located just off i-295 on saturday night. newline_char newline_char according to jso, rodarte admitted to killing gold and disposing of her body in the pond at the end of club duclay road. newline_char newline_char rodarte led police to the body, jso said. an autopsy is pending to confirm the remains are that of gold and to determine cause of death. newline_char newline_char jso said video surveillance showed a possible struggle inside rodarte's car. on the video, jso said, rodarte could be seen walking to gold's car, opening a door and looking inside. newline_char newline_char jso said rodarte returned to his car and drove off at 6:04 p.m. gold was never seen exiting the car, jso said. newline_char newline_char the company that owns bonefish grill released a statement sunday: newline_char newline_char "we are deeply saddened by the loss of savannah and will miss the joy and happiness she brought to work every day. our thoughts and deepest sympathies are with family and friends during this difficult time, including the people she worked with here at bonefish grill." newline_char newline_char the restaurant put a sign on their door sunday that said they were closed. newline_char newline_char gold was quickly reported missing wednesday after she didn’t show up for her shift at bonefish grill on san jose boulevard. newline_char newline_char about 30 minutes after gold was supposed to be at work, her father daniel said he got a text from gold’s phone. it had misspelled words and said she was running away with a great guy she met and would call them later. newline_char newline_char that was the moment gold’s parents said they knew something was wrong. newline_char newline_char “he showed it to me and i immediately knew that it wasn’t her," sharon gold said. "we text each other all day and every day … and this was not from my daughter. it was from someone else." newline_char newline_char gold's aunt created a gofundme account sunday to raise money for funeral expenses. newline_char newline_char updates on this story: get the free action news jax app newline_char newline_char facebook live: jso's steve gallaher announces discovery of body: newline_char newline_char gold's coworker was arrested after he admitted to killing her and dumping her body in a pond several miles away https://t.co/xgdmeraopw — brittney donovan (@brittneydonovan) august 6, 2017 newline_char newline_char © 2019 cox media group.

shortly after savannah gold headed to her job at the bonefish grill restaurant in jacksonville last wednesday, her family began receiving strange text messages from her phone. newline_char newline_char get push notifications with news, features and more. newline_char newline_char “hey i just wanted to tell you and mom i met a really great guy and we’re running away together,” she texted her father, according to a missing persons report. “i love him and we’re leaving tonight i’ll call you later when we get to where we are going.” newline_char newline_char her family instantly became suspicious. “the spelling was all whacked out,” her father, daniel gold, told wsb-tv. “it looked really strange.” newline_char newline_char gold never made it to work that day — but her car was found in the parking lot. “her car was outside with a slashed tire and her purse, with her id, credit cards and money [were] in the car with it unlocked,” daniel gold told the news station. “that really got us concerned.” newline_char newline_char savannah gold/facebook newline_char newline_char the jacksonville sheriff’s office interviewed 28-year-old lee rodarte jr., a bonefish grill culinary manager who allegedly had an on-again, off-again relationship with the 21-year-old gold. newline_char newline_char “the suspect when interviewed by police admitted to being in the bonefish grill parking lot with the victim, killing her, and disposing of her body” in a nearby lake, the sheriff’s office alleged in a statement. “rodarte led police to remains that were located by the jso dive team and we believe the remains to be savannah gold.” newline_char newline_char lee rodarte jacksonville sheriff's office newline_char newline_char the sheriff’s office says that they’re waiting for the medical examiner to officially identify the remains. newline_char newline_char surveillance video at the restaurant shows gold getting into rodarte’s car. police say that there was a “possible struggle” in the car before rodarte drove off. newline_char newline_char gold’s family told news4jax.com that rodarte spoke to them after her disappearance and expressed his concerns. they also say that he helped hand out missing persons flyers before speaking to police. newline_char newline_char authorities believe that rodarte was the one who sent the texts after gold’s death, jacksonville sheriff lieutenant steve gallagher told reporters. newline_char newline_char rodarte has been charged with murder and evidence tampering. he is jailed without bond at the duval county jail. he has not yet entered a plea, and it is unclear if he has retained an attorney.

summary: newline_char newline_char it's been a year since the women's march on washington drew an estimated half a million people to the nation's capital, one day after president donald trump's inauguration. newline_char newline_char in the months since, several high-profile women's marches have taken place throughout the country and around the world, and women have continued to speak out about sexual harassment, gender discrimination and the #metoo movement. newline_char newline_char women have also scored some significant victories in the political arena, including newline_char newline_char here's a look at some of the biggest moments for women in the past year: newline_char newline_char president trump is sworn into office newline_char newline_char trump's inauguration drew an estimated 700,000 people to washington, d.c., one day after the women's march drew an estimated half a million people to the nation's capital. newline_char newline_char the first female director of the c.i.a. newline_char newline_char in january, trump tapped gina haspel to serve as the first female director of the c.i.a. haspel

summary: – the boyfriend of a missing florida woman has been charged with murder after police say he dumped her body in a pond, reports the jacksonville sheriff's office. 28-year-old lee rodarte was arrested saturday after he led officers to the pond where the remains of savannah gold were found, reports the ap. he confessed to killing gold, 27, who was last seen getting into his car in the parking lot of the bonefish grill in san jose, about 30 minutes before she went to work. police say they found evidence of a struggle in the car, and that rodarte slashed the tire of gold's car. gold's father, daniel, tells cnn his daughter was "a great girl" who "did everything she could to help people." "we're just devastated," he says. "she did everything—people knew her that way." at her first court appearance on sunday, rodarte was ordered held without bond on the murder charge. he's also accused of tampering with evidence. gold's parents say they were "deeply saddened" by her disappearance and knew she was never seen with anyone else. they say they were told by someone at the restaurant who saw surveillance video of her getting into rodarte's car.

summary: – a jacksonville, florida, woman went missing this week and was found dead in a pond several miles away, the sheriff's office says. authorities say savannah gold, 21, didn't show up to work at the bonefish grill restaurant where she worked on wednesday. shortly after that, gold's father got a text from her phone with misspelled words, saying she was running away with a great guy she met. "it looked really strange," daniel gold tells wsb-tv. "her car was outside with a slashed tire and her purse, with her id, credit cards, and money [were] in the car with it unlocked." the sheriff's office says coworker lee rodarte, 28, confessed to killing gold and dumping her body in a pond, action news reports. rodarte was arrested sunday and charged with murder and evidence tampering. surveillance video shows him getting into gold's car and looking inside the car, according to jso. he then drove off. gold's family tells wsb-tv that rodarte spoke to them after her disappearance and expressed his concerns. they also say he helped hand out missing persons flyers before speaking to police. the company that owns bonefish grill released a statement sunday saying it was "deeply saddened by the loss of savannah and will miss the joy and happiness she brought to work every day."

documents: jerusalem — new archaeological tests have confirmed that the site many christians believe to be the tomb of jesus christ dates back 1,700 years to a.d. 325, the same era when the romans first identified the place as holy. newline_char newline_char with invasions, fires and even earthquakes occurring at jerusalem's church of the holy sepulchre over the centuries, historians had questioned whether the tomb had been destroyed or moved. newline_char newline_char to date the tomb, known as the holy edicule, conservators from the national technical university of athens looked at radioactive elements in the architectural glue that fit it together. they also used ground-penetrating radar and laser scanning. newline_char newline_char play facebook newline_char newline_char twitter newline_char newline_char embed today goes inside church of the holy sepulchre: is it jesus' tomb? 3:43 autoplay autoplay copy this code to your website or blog newline_char newline_char the tomb is the size of a coat closet, and was open for just 60 hours while restoration work was also carried out. newline_char newline_char the results of the tests were first reported tuesday by national geographic. newline_char newline_char "scientists and archaeologists are very excited about this because, what it does is, it corroborates our historical accounts," said national geographic archaeology writer kristin romey, who was on site during the nine-month renovation project. newline_char newline_char experts believe the site was identified around a.d. 325 a.d., when the roman emperor constantine the great came to the city with his team to locate places associated with the life of jesus. newline_char newline_char a holy fire ceremony is held at the church of the holy sepulchre in jerusalem on april 15. atef safadi / epa file newline_char newline_char the romans are said to have torn down a temple in jerusalem where they found the cave that they believed to be his burial site. they then built a shrine and a church around that site. newline_char newline_char three different christian denominations — roman catholic, greek orthodox and armenian orthodox — share custody over the church, and there have been turf wars and brawls in the past over the management of the site. newline_char newline_char even the restoration took decades to settle. in 1959, the various denominations agreed to conserve the edicule, but it took until 2016 to actually agree on a plan for the restoration, national geographic archaeologist-in-residence fredrik hiebert said. newline_char newline_char the same greek team that restored the acropolis in athens was chosen to carry out the project. newline_char newline_char archaeologists believe there may be more surprises to come at the site. newline_char newline_char “there is so much information in the data that was collected by the restorers during the conservation project,” hiebert said. “there are many, many stories still to be told.”

over the centuries, jerusalem’s church of the holy sepulchre has suffered violent attacks, fires, and earthquakes. it was totally destroyed in 1009 and subsequently rebuilt, leading modern scholars to question whether it could possibly be the site identified as the burial place of christ by a delegation sent from rome some 17 centuries ago. newline_char newline_char now the results of scientific tests provided to national geographic appear to confirm that the remains of a limestone cave enshrined within the church are remnants of the tomb located by the ancient romans. newline_char newline_char mortar sampled from between the original limestone surface of the tomb and a marble slab that covers it has been dated to around a.d. 345. according to historical accounts, the tomb was discovered by the romans and enshrined around 326. newline_char newline_char view images a restorer removes debris beneath a broken marble slab to expose the original rock surface of what is considered the burial place of jesus. photograph by oded balilty, ap for national geographic newline_char newline_char until now, the earliest architectural evidence found in and around the tomb complex dated to the crusader period, making it no older than 1,000 years. newline_char newline_char while it is archaeologically impossible to say that the tomb is the burial site of an individual jew known as jesus of nazareth, who according to new testament accounts was crucified in jerusalem in 30 or 33, new dating results put the original construction of today's tomb complex securely in the time of constantine, rome's first christian emperor. newline_char newline_char the tomb was opened for the first time in centuries in october 2016, when the shrine that encloses the tomb, known as the edicule, underwent a significant restoration by an interdisciplinary team from the national technical university of athens. newline_char newline_char several samples of mortar from different locations within the edicule were taken at that time for dating, and the results were recently provided to national geographic by chief scientific supervisor antonia moropoulou, who directed the edicule restoration project. newline_char newline_char when constantine's representatives arrived in jerusalem around 325 to locate the tomb, they were allegedly pointed to a roman temple built some 200 years earlier. the roman temple was razed and excavations beneath it revealed a tomb hewn from a limestone cave. the top of the cave was sheared off to expose the interior of the tomb, and the edicule was built around it. newline_char newline_char a feature of the tomb is a long shelf, or "burial bed," which according to tradition was where the body of jesus christ was laid out following crucifixion. such shelves and niches, hewn from limestone caves, are a common feature in tombs of wealthy 1st-century jerusalem jews. newline_char newline_char the marble cladding that covers the "burial bed" is believed to have been installed in 1555 at the latest, and most likely was present since the mid-1300s, according to pilgrim accounts. newline_char newline_char when the tomb was opened on the night of october 26, 2016, scientists were surprised by what they found beneath the marble cladding: an older, broken marble slab incised with a cross, resting directly atop the original limestone surface of the "burial bed." newline_char newline_char some researchers speculated that this older slab may have been laid down in the crusader period, while others offered an earlier date, suggesting that it may have already been in place and broken when the church was destroyed in 1009. no one, however, was ready to claim that this might be the first physical evidence for the earliest roman shrine on the site. newline_char newline_char is this really the tomb of christ? scholars discuss whether the tomb of christ is actually the tomb of christ and how it would have looked. newline_char newline_char the new test results, which reveal the lower slab was most likely mortared in place in the mid-fourth century under the orders of emperor constantine, come as a welcome surprise to those who study the history of the sacred monument. newline_char newline_char "obviously that date is spot-on for whatever constantine did," says archaeologist martin biddle, who published a seminal study on the history of the tomb in 1999. "that's very remarkable." newline_char newline_char during their year-long restoration of the edicule, the scientists were also able to determine that a significant amount of the burial cave remains enclosed within the walls of the shrine. mortar samples taken from remains of the southern wall of the cave were dated to 335 and 1570, which provide additional evidence for construction works from the roman period, as well as a documented 16th-century restoration. mortar taken from the tomb entrance has been dated to the 11th century and is consistent with the reconstruction of the edicule following its destruction in 1009. newline_char newline_char "it is interesting how [these] mortars not only provide evidence for the earliest shrine on the site, but also confirm the historical construction sequence of the edicule," moropoulou observes. newline_char newline_char the mortar samples were independently dated at two separate labs using optically stimulated luminescence (osl), a technique that determines when quartz sediment was most recently exposed to light. the scientific results will be published by moropoulou and her team in a forthcoming issue of the journal of archaeological science: reports. newline_char newline_char secrets of christ’s tomb premieres sunday december 3 at 9/8c on the national geographic channel. the immersive, 3-d exhibition " tomb of christ: the church of the holy sepulchre experience" is open at the national geographic museum in washington d.c. through the fall of 2018.

earlier date, suggesting that it may have already been in place and broken when the church was destroyed in 1009. no one, however, was ready to claim that this might be the first physical evidence for welcome surprise to those who study the history of the sacred monument. newline_char newline_char "obviously that date is spot-on for whatever constantine did," says archaeologist martin biddle, who published a seminal study on the history of the tomb in 1999. "that's very remarkable." newline_char newline_char during their year-long restoration of the edicule, the scientists were also able to determine that a significant amount of the burial cave remains enclosed within the walls of the shrine. mortar samples taken from remains of the southern wall of the cave were dated to 335 and 1570, which provide additional evidence for construction works from the roman period, as well as a documented 16th-century restoration. mortar taken from the tomb entrance has been dated to the 11th century and is consistent with the reconstruction of the edicule following its destruction in 1009. newline_char newline_char "it is interesting how [these] mortars not only provide evidence for the earliest shrine on the site, but also confirm the historical construction sequence of the edicule," moropoulou observes. newline_char newline_char the mortar samples were independently dated at two separate labs using optically stimulated luminescence (osl), a technique that determines when quartz sediment was most recently exposed to light. the scientific results will be published by moropoulou and her team in a forthcoming issue of the journal of archaeological science: reports. newline_char newline_char secrets of christ’s tomb premieres sunday december 3 at 9/8c on the national geographic channel. the immersive, 3-d exhibition " tomb of christ: the church of the holy sepulchre experience" is open at the national geographic museum in washington d.c. through the fall of 2018. |||||
summary: New archaeological tests have confirmed that the site many Christians believe to be the tomb of Jesus Christ dates back 1,700 years to A.D. 325, the same era when the Romans first identified the place as holy. With invasions, fires and even earthquakes occurring at Jerusalem's Church of the Holy Sepulchre over the centuries, historians had questioned whether the tomb had been destroyed or moved. To date the tomb, known as the Holy Edicule, conservators from the National Technical University of Athens looked at radioactive elements in the architectural glue that fit it together. They also used ground-penetrating radar and laser scanning. The results of the tests were first reported by National Geographic. The tomb is the size of a coat closet, and was open for just 60 hours while restoration work was also carried out. Experts believe the site was identified around A.D. 325, when the Roman Emperor Constantine the Great came to the city with his team to locate places associated with the life of Jesus. The Romans are said to have torn down a temple in Jerusalem where they found the cave that they believed to be his burial site. They then built a shrine and a church around that site. The Church of the Holy Sep

summary: – more than 100 years of searching and 10 years of restoration work have finally yielded the answer to jesus christ's final resting place: the church of the holy sepulchre in jerusalem, greece. the ancient roman emperor constantine the great first identified the site as jesus' tomb in 325 bc, and according to greek geographic, the tomb was securely located there until the 1970s. now, after taking advantage of modern technology to date the tomb, conservators from the national technical university of athens have confirmed that it actually was there, livescience reports. they used tools including ground-penetrating radar and laser scanning to determine the position of the tomb, as well as radioactive elements in the walls and ceiling. the church was closed to the public during the restoration work but reopened to the public in april. during that time, the tomb was open to the public for just 60 hours, but the results of the tests mean "there is no evidence of any movement or destruction of the tomb," said a greek geographic archaeologist. what's more, the ancient romans are said to have torn down a temple in jerusalem where they found the cave that they believed to be jesus' burial site.

first identified the place as holy. newline_char newline_char with invasions, fires and even earthquakes occurring at jerusalem's church of the holy sepulchre over the centuries, historians had questioned whether the tomb had been destroyed or moved. newline_char newline_char to date the tomb, known as the holy edicule, conservators from the national technical university of athens looked at national geographic. newline_char newline_char "scientists and archaeologists are very excited about this because, what it does is, it corroborates our historical accounts," said national geographic the results of scientific tests provided to national geographic appear to confirm that the remains of a limestone cave enshrined within the church are remnants of the tomb located by the ancient romans. newline_char newline_char mortar sampled from between the original limestone surface of the tomb and a marble slab that covers it has been dated to around a.d. 345. according to historical summary: – after decades of uncertainty, archaeologists have finally determined that the tomb of christ is actually the birthplace of jesus of nazareth, according to the new testament. the tomb, located at jerusalem's church of the holy sepulchre, was opened for just 60 hours in october 2016 during a year-long restoration project. scientists were surprised to find a broken marble slab, incised with a cross, resting directly atop the surface of the tomb's "burial bed," which according to tradition was where the body of jesus was laid out following crucifixion. some researchers speculate that the slab may have been laid down in the crusader period, while others suggest that it may have already been in place and broken when the church was destroyed in 1009. the new scientific results, however, come as a welcome surprise to those who study the history of the sacred monument. "obviously that date is spot-on for whatever constantine did," says archaeologist martin biddle, who published a seminal study on the history of the tomb in 1999. "that's very remarkable." the national geographic museum's immersive, 3-d exhibition "tomb of christ: the church of the holy sepulchre experience" is open through the fall of 2018.

the obama campaign is using a mailer modeled after online cat memes as part of their final get out the vote push in the crucial battleground state of ohio. on the mailer, there is a picture of a cat peeking out from behind a laptop decorated with ohio-themed obama campaign stickers highlighting the push to get people to vote early. newline_char newline_char “stop looking at cats online and go vote,” text on the flyer says. newline_char newline_char a user on the social news site reddit with the handle mollybloom11 posted a picture of the mailer on the site last night. they were clearly impressed with the campaign’s understanding of internet culture. newline_char newline_char “the obama campaign sent me this today…they know their audience,” mollybloom11 wrote. newline_char newline_char the obama campaign confirmed the mailer was real and has been used in ohio. they were not immediately sure whether similar imaging has been used for online ads or in other states. newline_char newline_char follow hunter walker on twitter or via rss. hwalker@observer.com

summary: – mitt romney is hoping some last-minute politico magic will help him upend barack obama in ohio, where polls show the race tightening. the romney campaign announced today that it had raised $1 million in the 24 hours ending at midnight, reports politico. that's about the same amount as the obama campaign had raised in the same period. other key donors to romney include kelsey grammer, john elway, bob barker, and sarah palin, reports the daily beast. gop: the obama campaign is using a mailer modeled after online cat memes as part of their final get out the vote push in the crucial battleground state of ohio, the ohio hunter reports. the flyer, which has been circulating on twitter and reddit, shows a picture of a cat peeking out from behind a laptop decorated with ohio-themed obama campaign stickers. the text on the flyer reads, in part, "stop looking at cats online and go vote," accompanied by a cat emoji. it's not clear whether the kitties are real or not, but a user on the social news site reddit spotted a picture of the mailer on the site last night and posted it to the rss feed, suggesting it was indeed authentic. the obama campaign did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

"stop looking at cats online and go vote," the text on the flyer says. the campaign confirmed the mailer was real and has been used in ohio, but it's not clear if it's been used in other states. in other obama-related news, the zach galifianakis, renee zellweger, susan saint james ebersol, and amanda seyfried are among the four-figure donors in recent days to the obama campaign, per the new york times. for romney, kelsey grammer, denver broncos executive john elway, and bob barker have made 11th hour donations. “the obama campaign sent me this today…they know their audience,” mollybloom11 writes on the site. they were clearly impressed with the campaign’s understanding of internet culture. documents: but lerner should have been gone shortly after this scandal first unraveled in the press. not only is she the person who was in charge of the group that wrongly targeted conservatives, she dishonestly testified that she didn’t know about the targeting until 2012, when the inspector general found she knew as early as 2011. she’s the person who told a conference call of reporters, “i’m not that good at math,” even though she’s a manager in an agency that’s at bottom all about math. newline_char newline_char what i think is even more politically and morally suspect – and has gotten very little attention -- lerner actually presided over the bizarre, bumbling rollout of the story, by planting a question about the controversy with an attorney at an american bar association conference. according to morgan lewis tax lawyer celia roady, lerner herself asked that roady inquire about whether the irs had targeted conservative groups. that led to lerner’s public apology – and the scandal swirling around the white house, which found itself surprised by the sudden disclosure. newline_char newline_char the invaluable tax-policy expert david cay johnston called for lerner’s firing a week ago – and that was even before there was proof that she had set up the question at the aba conference.

lois lerner, the irs staffer who is under fire for her role in the agency’s targeting of conservative groups, has been placed on administrative leave, according to congressional aides. newline_char newline_char newline_char newline_char she will still be paid while on leave, a congressional aide said, as required under civil service rules. newline_char newline_char lerner, who heads an irs division that oversees tax-exempt groups, first disclosed the extra scrutiny the agency gave to tea party groups almost two weeks ago when answering a planted question at a washington legal conference. newline_char newline_char since then, lawmakers from across the political spectrum have said that they believe lerner misled them and have called for her dismissal. newline_char lerner to resign — and that lerner was only placed on leave after she declined that request. aides on capitol hill confirmed that lerner had refused to resign. newline_char newline_char in her first dishonestly testified that she didn’t know about the targeting until 2012, when the inspector general found she knew as early as 2011. she’s the person who told a conference call of reporters, “i’m not that good at math,” even though she’s a manager in an agency that’s at bottom all about math. newline_char newline_char what i think is even more politically and morally suspect – and has gotten conference. according to morgan lewis tax lawyer celia roady, lerner herself asked that roady inquire about whether the irs had targeted conservative groups. that led to lerner’s public apology – and summary: -Lois Lerner, the irs staffer who was in charge of the group that targeted conservatives, has been placed on administrative leave after refusing to resign. -Lerner is accused of dishonestly testifying that she didn’t know about the targeting until 2012, when the inspector general found she knew as early as 2011. -The new study suggests that the practice is far more common that thought, reports inside higher ed. -The university of houston survey rounded up nearly 1,200 students who had at least one bout of heavy drinking in the previous month and found that eight in 10 had engaged in at least one behavior linked to drunkorexia.

summary: – one of the key players in the irs controversy has been put on leave, reports the hill. lois lerner, the head of the tax-exempt division that handled applications for tax-exempt status, has been placed on leave, congressional aides say. she's been under fire since it was revealed that the agency had improperly targeted conservative groups for additional scrutiny starting in 2011. lerner first disclosed the extra scrutiny the agency gave to tea party groups during a conference call with reporters last week. when asked by a lawyer at a bar association conference whether the irs had targeted conservative groups, she initially said she didn't know about it. but a subsequent inspector general report found that irs officials had been targeting groups for similar scrutiny starting in 2011. ernie werfel, who's now the acting irs commissioner, has asked lerner to resign, a senior republican on the finance committee tells the washington post. werfel's office confirmed the move, although it noted that lerner had already been on leave since wednesday. lerner's lawyer tells the hill that she had nothing to do with the question she asked at the bar conference.
